developer.name: GlassLab, Inc.
developer.description:
GlassLab brings together leaders in commercial games and experts in learning and assessment to develop next generation digital games and interactive experiences that make learning visible. Our products and services are designed to deliver proven learning impact and reach youth in schools, informal learning environments, and at home.

The Lab represents a groundbreaking collaboration between Educational Testing Service, Electronic Arts, the Entertainment Software Association, Institute of Play, Pearson's Center for Digital Data, Analytics & Adaptive Learning, Zynga, and others.

GlassLab is made possible through the generous support of The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

headers.title: Sunflowers in front of lane
headers.description: Student places sunflowers near the front of the lane where they are more vulnerable.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student why they are placing sunflowers near the front to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to understand the givens by asking:
actionPoints: What do sunflowers do?
Can they attack the zombies?
What happens if the zombies attack the sunflowers?
Where does it make the most sense to plant the sunflowers? Why?

headers.title: Walnuts in back of lane
headers.description: Student places walnuts near the back of the lane where they can't protect other plants.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student why they are placing the walnut near the back to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to use the tool more effectively by asking:
actionPoints: What do walnuts do?
Can they attack the zombies?
What happens if the zombies attack the walnuts?
Where does it make the most sense to plant the walnuts? Why?

headers.title: Potato mines diffused
headers.description: Student places potato mines such that they are diffused before arming.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student how they are using potato mines to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to use the tool more effectively by asking:
actionPoints: What do potato mines do?
Can zombies eat the mines?
How can you tell if a mine will defeat a zombie or be eaten?
Where does it make the most sense to plant the potato mines? Why?

headers.title: Not enough sunflowers
headers.description: Student places less than 4 sunflowers before the second wave of zombies.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student what the purpose of sunflowers is to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to feel confident in exploring more options by asking:
actionPoints: What happens if you don't plant any sunflowers?
What happens if you only plant sunflowers?
What is the best number of sunflowers to plant? Why?

headers.title: Not collecting sun
headers.description: Student collects less than (RATIO * 100) % of sun produced.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student what the purpose of the suns are to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to understand the givens by asking:
actionPoints: Why do you need to collect suns?
What happens if you don't collect it?
How long do you have before it disappears?
What is the ideal strategy when it comes to picking up suns? Why?

headers.title: Inefficient plant food use
headers.description: Student uses plant food in situations that don't require it.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student what plant food is for to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to use the tool more effectively by asking:
actionPoints: When do you tend to use it?
How many times can you use it on a level?
Does it work differently depending on the type of plant?
When does it make sense to use it on one plant versus another?
What situations make the most sense for using plant food?

headers.title: Losing to difficult zombies
headers.description: Student is defeated when fast, tough, or many zombies are in a lane.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student what has been defeating them and how they have tried to defend against it to get a sense of their tihnking. Help the student to plan effectively by asking:
actionPoints: What is your defense for large groups of zombies in one lane?
What is your defense for tough zombies?
What is your defense for fast zombies?
What else can you try to use to stop them?

headers.title: Not improving plant layout
headers.description: Student is not trying a more effective plant layout when retrying a level.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student how they like to arrange their plants to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to plan effectively by asking:
actionPoints: What types of plants do you use?
Where do you like to plant them?
What would happen if you placed that plant more toward the front or the back?
Is there a better way to arrange the plants?

headers.title: Ineffective use of shovel
headers.description: Student is not using the shovel to strengthen their lanes.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student how they use the shovel to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to use the tool more effectively by asking:
actionPoints: Why would you want to remove a plant?
Is there a time when a plant isn't being effective? Why?
Is there a time when you want to replace a plant with a different one? Why?

headers.title: Not replacing eaten plants
headers.description: Student is not replacing plants quickly after they are eaten.

whatNow.intro: Ask the student what they do when a plant gets eaten to get a sense of their thinking. Help the student to evaluate their progress by asking:
actionPoints: What happens when a zombie eats one of your plants?
What does it mean for your overall progress?
How can you maintain the safety of that lane?
How does it impact your sun?
What is the best way to deal with a plant being eaten?

list.description: This report provides a snapshot of how students are doing right now. Celebrate your students' success (Shout Out!) and intervene with those students in need of help (Watch Out!).

product.title: Product Description
product.about: Developed in collaboration with PopCap/Electronic Arts and researchers at Florida State University, Plants vs. Zombies EDU assesses the critical competency of problem solving. In this game, players must outwit some very hungry zombies who are desperately trying to make it across a garden to invade your home and eat your brain. To thwart that effort, players must strategically plant a garden filled with powerful plant obstacles, each with different properties designed to keep those zombies at bay. The game keeps the fun of the popular commercial title, and on the surface is not significantly different. However, what makes Plants vs. Zombies EDU different is that GlassLab has added a layer underneath the game to capture evidence of student problem solving skills, turning an awesome game into a powerful alternative assessment vehicle.
curriculum: A cornerstone of academic and career success, problem solving is an essential skill that reaches across disciplines. The lesson plans that accompany the game, are focussed on grades 6-8 math, and offer a systematic approach to breaking problems down and developing problem solving strategies. Educators will have access to reports showing students overall ability and the following subcomponents of problem solving
Effective & efficient use of tools and resources

list.name: CCSS.MATH.PRACTICE.MP1
list.description: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.

list.name: CCSS.MATH.PRACTICE.MP3
list.description: Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.

list.name: CCSS.MATH.PRACTICE.MP7
list.description: Look for and make use of structure.

list.name: CCSS.MATH.PRACTICE.MP8
list.description: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

list.name: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.RP
list.description: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

list.name: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.RP
list.description: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
